Jimisola: Is this the same for you?

Marko - how do the build class paths between the old and the new projects 
differ? Do both projects refer the same junit.jar?

Both are plugin projects (sorry, forgot to mention that). 

Junit is a project in the workspace which they both require in their plugin.xml
and after "Update Buildpath" JUnit shows up in Properties->Java Build
Path->Libraries->Plug-in Dependencies->org.junit .


The OldProj also has other plug-in requirements. Removing them results in some
compiler error (of course) in other classes, but the mentioned test class still
cannot be run (after the warning about the compiler errors)

OK, I found the crucial difference between the two projects: The project, in
which the error occurs, contains a tilde (~) in its project name. This also
causes the refactoring problem I described as a sidenote (which is handled in
bug 47815).

As soon as I remove all tildes from the project name JUnit works again.



Jimisola, do you also have special characters in your project name?

This means the VM running the tests cannot be launched because of the special 
characters. Can you please paste in the resulting command line:
1) run the JUnit test
2) switch to the debug view
3) select the child (process node) of the JUnit node
4) properties
-> the command line shows up in the properties dialog

The command line is the same (besides the always changing port number), whether
JUnit starts successfully or not.


After further investigation and debugging a run-time workbench, in which I
startet the tests, it seems to me, that the problem with the special characters
really is the same as in bug 47815:

I tracked the problem to JUnitPlugin.java, line 248: 
    IJavaElement element= JavaCore.create(typeStr);

Here JavaCore.create() returns a null, propable because of the tilde in typeStr.
So my problem really seems to lie in the domain of JavaCore.
